In response to these ongoing crises facing vets, in honor of our veterans who have given so much, & w/ gratitude to Vet Center counselors nationwide, I introduced the bipartisan Vet CENTERS for Mental Health Act, which will increase the number of Vet Centers across this country.

Despite the high-quality care Vet Centers provide, not everyone has access and far too many of our veterans nationwide continue to suffer mental health issues and all too often fall victim to drug abuse, homelessness, suicide or other ills as a result of a this lack of care.

While the Bloomfield Vet Center is doing a great job serving our communities, the case load they are experiencing is immense, especially in the wake of the pandemic. North Jersey needs an additional center to help address this.

Vet Centers are often seen as the gold standard in mental health care for these veterans. In August I was honored to visit the staff at the Bloomfield Vet Center to meet with the mental health professionals who care for those who have served and hear them discuss their work. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBqeV8yWQAE1U6d.jpg

Since that time the Vet Center mission has expanded to include support for veterans who were victims of military sexual assault, bereavement services, and services for our national guard and reservists.

In 1979, in the wake of the Vietnam war, the VA stood up Veteran Centers for mental health counseling.  These institutions were uniquely designed to support veterans who faced the trauma of combat, as well as offer aid and support to their families.

At the end of last week, I introduced a bipartisan bill that would expand one of the key parts of our VA health system that routinely offers lifesaving mental health aid to our nation‚Äôs veterans and address the critical need for it here in North Jersey. üßµ
